Description: Body sherd of Laconian black-figured pottery open vessel, possibly a kylix; dull cream slip; interior: black-figure decoration, perhaps two male figures; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of lower part of confronting hoplites (greaved leg and part of round shield with added red of warrior on the left, one leg and lower part of round shield of that on right); between them, bird with red on wing standing to right; small incised spoked rosettes as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
'Lak' is written in pencil on the exterior surface of the sherd.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 556, no. E26)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 37, pl. XVIII, no. 45)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GC.70) (phase 3)
